rules.description: Use Markdown H1 headings.
Aim for 50 to 60 characters; 80 characters maximum.
Start with an action verb in the imperative form and avoid the -ing form of the verb.
Capitalize only the first word and any proper nouns using sentence-style capitalization.
Focus the title on the outcome rather than the mechanics.
examples: instead of "Install Node.js and create a project directory", use "Set up a local development environment for Node.js".

rules.description: Include the action and the object or context so the goal is unambiguous.
Avoid one- or two-word titles and avoid empty verbs like make, manage, or put.
Do not use punctuation marks such as colons, semicolons, or dashes in the title except for the required "Step {n}:" prefix.

examples.Example: Create a codespace from a template
Creating a codespace from a template
Use source control in your codespace
Collaborate with others in a codespace
Set up a live share session

sections.title: Subtitle

rules.description: Use a Markdown H4 for the subtitle placed directly under the H1 title.
Write the subtitle as one sentence only with no links, lists, or inline formatting.
End the subtitle with a period.
Keep the subtitle under 20 words.
Use neutral verbs that state the purpose or benefit and avoid persuasive language.
Add new value beyond the title without repeating or rephrasing the H1.

examples: **Title**: *Quickstart for GitHub Actions* / **Subtitle**: *Try out the core features of GitHub Actions in minutes*
**Title**: *Create a pull request* / **Subtitle**: *Create a pull request to propose and collaborate on changes to a repository*

sections.title: Access callout

rules.description: Omit the access callout entirely if no permission or product constraints exist.
Place the access callout after the title and subtitle and before the introduction.
Use the Note callout style for the access callout.
Use label-led, scannable content in the access callout and avoid explanations.
Include permissions such as software roles or permission levels in the access callout when applicable.
Include product version or edition information in the access callout when applicable.
Use commas to separate multiple permissions or products in the access callout.
Do not include knowledge, skills, or required tools in the access callout.

examples: **Note** - **Permissions**: Node operators, Site operators - **Product**: Logos Storage v1.4.0 or later

sections.title: Callouts

rules.description: Use callouts sparingly and avoid placing them consecutively.
Use at most one callout per section.
Keep each callout concise with no more than two short sentences and move longer content into the body under a heading.
Ensure callout content is directly relevant to the nearby task or decision point.
Use the appropriate callout type of Tip, Note, Important, or Caution.
Do not include full procedural steps or long prerequisite checklists inside callouts and keep steps in the main flow and prerequisite lists in "Before you start."
Refer to the writing rules for the allowed callout types and when to use them.

examples: **Note:** Keep container resources within the documented limits to avoid throttling.

rules.description: Treat the Intro section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body for it.
Include intro components in the order Overview, Decisions (optional), Limits (optional), Impact (optional), and Prerequisites (optional).
Render the child blocks Overview, Decisions, Limits, Impact, and Prerequisites without their own headings.
Render the overview inline under the Intro section without a visible subheading.
Write a 50–100 word paragraph explaining what the procedure covers, why it matters, and when to use it.
State where the procedure applies and who the intended audience is.
Optionally include one concrete real-world scenario in a single sentence.
Use at most one short alert in the overview only if it prevents confusion and otherwise keep the section free of callouts.
Render the decisions content inline under the Intro section without a visible subheading.
Summarize decisions the reader must make before starting the procedure.
Use a list for simple choices and use a compact table for multi-factor comparisons.
Focus decisions on actionable factors such as performance, complexity, cost, prerequisites, and limitations.
State trade-offs in the decisions content explicitly.
Provide clear guidance on how to choose between options.
examples: , "Choose A if you need X; choose B if you need Y".

rules.description: Link to a dedicated decision guide if the decision space is complex.
Render the limits content inline under the Intro section without a visible subheading.
Describe constraints as a short paragraph and use a list or table only if it improves scanning.
Cover quotas, rate limits, timeouts, eventual consistency, and destructive side effects in the limits section.
Use a single concise callout to surface a constraint that is critical to success or safety.
Mention a workaround or mitigation strategy for constraints when useful.
Link to a dedicated limitations page if the details are lengthy.
Render the impact content inline under the Intro section without a visible subheading.
Use a paragraph, list, or table to describe impact.
Highlight side effects and risks in the impact section.
Note required privileges or safer alternatives in the impact section when relevant.
Use a single concise callout for critical security impacts and link out for details.
Render prerequisites inline under the Intro section without a visible subheading.
List only the technical setup needed to run the procedure such as software, versions, tools, and configuration.
Do not include roles, permissions, or product variants in prerequisites and put them in the access callout instead.
Prefer a single brief bullet list of noun phrases for prerequisites and link to install or setup instructions as needed.
Use a Markdown H2 with the exact text "What to expect" for this section.
Place the "What to expect" section after the introduction and before the first task section.
Include exactly one unordered list with three items and do not include code blocks or callouts in it.
Write one complete sentence per bullet, with at most two short sentences, and end sentences with a period.
Use parallel wording in each bullet with the same grammatical shape focused on outcomes users will have after completing the procedure.
Order list items from most important to least important.
Allow only same-page heading links in this section and disallow external links.
Use Markdown H2 headings for procedure section titles.
Aim for task titles of 50–60 characters with a maximum of 80 characters.
Make the first task title "Step 1:" followed by the task name and increment the step number by one in subsequent task titles.
Start each task title with an imperative verb and avoid the -ing form.
Use sentence case in task titles by capitalizing only the first word and proper nouns.
Avoid empty verbs such as make, manage, or put in task titles.
Avoid task titles that contain only one or two words.
Do not use punctuation marks such as colons, semicolons, or dashes in task titles.
Write one or two short sentences in the task intro that provide context.
Do not repeat the task title wording in the task intro.
Add cross-references in the task intro rather than inside steps.
Place a single callout after the task intro for important notes, warnings, or tips.
Do not place callouts between steps in a task.
Use at most one callout per task.
Use a numbered list when the task is completed in one sequence.
Use checkboxes when steps are unordered or spread over time.
Ensure each "Step {n}" section contains exactly one list of actions.
Start each step with an imperative verb and avoid -ing forms.
Map one step to one user action and combine only trivial actions.
Write ordered lists with "1." for every item in the Markdown source.
Aim for 2–7 steps in a task and split the task if it is longer.
Avoid tasks that contain only one step.
When adding paragraphs, images, or code under a step insert a blank line and indent so they are children of that step.
Bold UI elements such as buttons, menus, and options in steps.
Use inline code formatting for commands, filenames, paths, and output in steps.
Use only same-page anchors in steps and do not use external links.
For UI paths put the location before the action in the step text.
For conditional statements write the result first and then the condition.

examples.Incorrect (condition first): If the Network Status is "Disconnected", an error message will display.
examples.Correct (result first): An error message will display if the Network Status is "Disconnected".

examples.Incorrect (condition first): Only use the `$API_KEY` if you are calling the external service.
examples.Correct (result first): Use the `$API_KEY` only if you are calling the external service.

rules.description: Do not use numbered substeps beneath a step or nested ordered lists for clarifiers.
Use bullet lists for subactions such as clarifiers or alternatives under a step.
Limit clarifier bullets to 2–4 items at one level.

sections.title: Step code
sections.format: Fenced code block under the step (3)

rules.description: Follow the code formatting rules defined in the writing rules when adding step code.

examples: 1. Do this thing... ```bash gh workflow run build --repo org/repo ```

rules.description: Follow the screenshot formatting rules defined in the writing rules when adding step screenshots.
Use an H2 Markdown heading for the FAQ or Troubleshooting section.
Place the FAQ or Troubleshooting section after the final procedure section and before "Next steps" if present.
Begin the section title with "Troubleshooting {topic}" for error resolution or "Frequently asked questions" for question-based content.
Use paragraphs, lists, or H3 headings for the FAQ or Troubleshooting content.
Write H3 question headings in sentence case and end them with a question mark.
Use the term "Frequently asked questions" instead of "FAQ" alone.
Create a separate FAQ or Troubleshooting concept article and link to it for longer or complex cases.
Treat the Extra guidelines section as guidance only and do not render a visible heading or body for it.
Keep the overall procedure word count between 400 and 800 words.
Do not use H4–H6 headings in the procedure template.
Do not include a "Further reading" section or links to other related topics at the end of the document.
